title: Alabama basketball rebounding woes resurface in Arizona loss | Goodbread
description: Alabama basketball couldn't compete on the glass against No. 1 ranked Arizona Saturday, lost in a rout, and Jimi Hendrix summed it up well.
fullText:
BIRMINGHAM ‚Äî The Jimi Hendrix rendition of "All Along the Watchtower" blasted loudly through Legacy Arena as the Alabama basketball team walked off the floor as losers of a blowout, summed up perfectly how the Crimson Tide must have been feeling.

There must be some way out of here, said the joker to the thief.

There‚Äôs too much confusion, I can‚Äôt get no relief.

Alabama was looking for a way out of the building as fast as possible, but have no confusion about this: Rebounding was the reason. Arizona 96, Alabama 75.

HIGHLIGHTS: Alabama basketball vs Arizona live updates, highlights from C.M. Newton Classic

Pushing the Crimson Tide (7-3) around under the basket is the book being written by opponents on this Nate Oats team, and it's not a first edition. It's been UA's undoing more often than not when things don't go well in the Oats era; the Wildcats ‚Äî ranked No. 1 in the nation ‚Äî were just the latest to expose it on Saturday night.

Arizona dominated the boards 52-32.

The neutral floor, of course, didn't sound neutral at all. A lively pro-Alabama crowd roared for about a half, until the top team in America started playing like it. By the end of a 28-6 Arizona run that took roughly nine minutes off the second-half clock, the outcome had been decided, fans at the BJCC were sitting on their hands, and the Crimson Tide's rebounders might as well have been doing the same.

Of course, that 28-6 hammer, during which Oats stubbornly declined to call a timeout, was punctuated by more than just rebounding problems. The shooting went cold, the defense lapsed, and lest anyone forget, a Final-Four threat of an Arizona team just played some really good basketball. But nothing exposed where the Crimson Tide needs to improve more than the rebounding disparity. Arizona piled up 22 offensive rebounds to Alabama's three. That translated into 28 more field goal attempts for the Wildcats, which Oats lamented as the determining factor.

In one maddening sequence in the second half, Crimson Tide center Aiden Sherrell and forward Amari Allen blocked two shots in four seconds, but gave up five offensive rebounds on the same possession, ultimately yielding a layup for a 55-48 Arizona lead. Alabama's defense recorded a whopping 15 blocks, led by Sherrell's eight, but allowed far too many second and third shots to have a chance at upending the Wildcats.

Beating Alabama up under the glass might be the right song for opponents, but only a few of them can sing it. The Crimson Tide's three losses have come at the hands of the nation's No. 1, No. 5 and No. 12 teams, but the same problem cropped up in all of them.

"This has been a recurring issue with us," Oats said. "Purdue, I think we lost (in rebounding) by 24. Gonzaga beat us. When we've played these tough, physical teams, we haven't answered the bell real well on the glass."

SEC play is three weeks away for Oats, and when it comes to rebounding woes, he must find a way out.

Tuscaloosa News columnist Chase Goodbread is also the weekly co-host of Crimson Cover TV on WVUA-23. Reach him at cgoodbread@gannett.com. Follow on X.com @chasegoodbread.

This article originally appeared on The Tuscaloosa News: Alabama basketball rebounding woes resurface in ugly loss to Arizona

title: Wemby shines on comeback as Spurs stun Thunder, Knicks down Magic
description:
Victor Wembanyama made a triumphant return from injury to lead the San Antonio Spurs to a stunning NBA Cup semi-final upset of the Oklahoma City Thunder on Saturday as the New York Knicks downed the Orlando Magic to book their place in the final.- Brunson stars for Knicks -
In Saturday's other semi-final, Jalen Brunson scored 40 points to power the New York Knicks to their first NBA Cup final with a 132-120 win over the Orlando Magic.
fullText:
Victor Wembanyama made a triumphant return from injury to lead the San Antonio Spurs to a stunning NBA Cup semi-final upset of the Oklahoma City Thunder on Saturday as the New York Knicks downed the Orlando Magic to book their place in the final.

French prodigy Wembanyama, who has missed the Spurs' last 12 games after suffering a left calf strain last month, produced a dominant performance at both ends of the court to set up a thrilling 111-109 victory at Las Vegas's T-Mobile Arena.

The 7ft 4in (2.24m) 21-year-old finished with 22 points, nine rebounds and two blocks in 21 minutes on court, helping the Spurs climb out of a 16-point hole in the second quarter to inflict only the second Oklahoma City defeat this season.

NBA champions Oklahoma City had gone into the game on the back of a 16-game winning streak, boasting a 24-1 record for the season that had prompted talk of them breaking Golden State's record 73-win season.

But after making a smooth start to control the game, Wembanyama began to make his presence felt off the bench in the second quarter to breathe new life into the San Antonio ranks.

"I knew I had limited minutes so I had to make the most out of it," Wembanyama said.

"Winning against a team like this, it might seem like it's just a game but it's a collective effort and it's not an easy thing.

"It's only their second loss of the season. It means something."

Wembanyama was one of four San Antonio players to finish with double figures, with Devin Vassell scoring 23, and Stephon Castle and De'Aaron Fox adding 22 apiece.

"It says a lot. And it says a lot about where this team is going to be in the future," he said.

Reigning NBA Most Valuable Player Shai Gilgeous-Alexander led the Thunder scoring with 29 points, while Jalen Williams and Chet Holmgren added 17 points each.

In Saturday's other semi-final, Jalen Brunson scored 40 points to power the New York Knicks to their first NBA Cup final with a 132-120 win over the Orlando Magic.

The Knicks' in-form offense proved too hot for injury-hit Orlando as New York took their recent streak to nine wins from 10 games.

"We came out here and did exactly what we said we wanted to do, which was play Knicks basketball," said Karl-Anthony Towns, who backed Brunson with 29 points.

The Magic had led 36-33 after making a rapid start to a breathless opening quarter -- earning the Knicks players some harsh and fiery words from coach Mike Brown in an early timeout.

"The way they came out, physicality-wise, we weren't ready for it," said Brunson.

"We bounced back and responded to that, and the way we played the rest of the game is a testament to that first timeout."

New York went on a tear at the start of the second quarter, capitalizing on a missed floating jump shot from Desmond Bane to take the lead through Josh Hart.

The Knicks briefly relinquished their advantage soon after half-time, when Bane put the Magic back ahead with a running layup.

But Orlando ultimately could not keep pace with Brunson, who late in the third quarter left opposing guard Anthony Black sitting helplessly on the floor before executing a three-point step-back jumpshot.

Orlando's Jalen Suggs managed a team-high 26 points, but failed to complete the game after suffering with an apparent injury to his left side.

The Magic also felt the absence of Franz Wagner, their leading scorer this season.

The NBA Cup, a mid-season knockout tournament now in its third year, is proving a hit with audiences and players.

It now offers a tantalizing opportunity for the Knicks to win their first overall trophy since 1973.

title: Analysis: No. 10 BYU explodes offensively in 47-point win over UC Riverside
description: Another career night from AJ Dybantsa and strong bench contributions powered the Cougars past the Highlanders.
fullText:
When BYU took the Marriott Center floor Saturday night, it was the Cougars‚Äô first appearance at their home arena in 32 days.

And what a 32 day stretch it was.

Over that span, BYU hopped on three separate flights to the east coast and two bus trips up to Salt Lake City.

The Cougars played in six Quad 1 or 2 contests ‚Äî winning five ‚Äî and captured a Thanksgiving tournament championship in Florida.

BYU took blue blood UConn down to the wire in Boston, blew out ranked foe Wisconsin at the Delta Center and stormed back to stun Clemson at the buzzer in New York City‚Äôs famed Madison Square Garden.

As eventful as the past 32 days were for the Cougars, it clearly made them a much better team, which was quite evident as BYU stomped UC Riverside 100-53 in Saturday‚Äôs long-awaited return to Provo.

‚ÄúI mean, this place always has energy,‚Äù BYU head coach Kevin Young said after the game. ‚ÄúThat trip to New York (earlier this week) was great, but it was exhausting. We felt like we were there forever, honestly. We had a pretty exhausting day the day after the game. It took us an hour and 40 minutes to get to the airport, and then we had a five-hour flight.

‚ÄúIt was a long day, so I was honestly a little worried about a letdown getting back home just in terms of like letting our guard down, but that was clearly not the case, so kudos to the guys to respond.‚Äù

Such a response came in the form of BYU‚Äôs best offensive showing of the young season, as it crossed the century mark in points and averaging a blistering 1.389 points per possession.

HERE YOU GO @SportsCenter ü§Ø

üì∫ ESPN+ | #SCTop10 pic.twitter.com/KQrpnstoyn

‚Äî BYU Men's Basketball (@BYUMBB) December 14, 2025

After being plagued by slow starts throughout the year, the Cougars instead came out swinging to the tune of 49 first half points before pouring on another 51 after halftime.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just trying to bring the mentality we have in second halves to the first half,‚Äù said AJ Dybantsa. ‚ÄúObviously, we‚Äôve been coming out pretty lazy. Our second halves have been good, so we just wanted to bring that same mentality to the first half.‚Äù

The Cougars shot 59.1% from the field and 47.4% from 3-point range, dishing out 22 collective assists, scoring 54 paint points, another 29 points in transition and even getting a season-high 36 points from their bench.

‚ÄúThere were a couple of things we wanted to highlight or emphasize coming into this game, and the No. 1 thing offensively was just playing with the pass 

‚Äú... (We) subsequently had the most fast break points with 29 fast break points, which is easier to do when you‚Äôre getting stops obviously, and then 22 assists, you know, that‚Äôs more how we want to play, and I thought the guys were really good there.‚Äù

Fresh off his finest performance to date against Clemson earlier this week, Dybantsa dazzled yet again on his home floor, scoring a game-high 26 points on 11 of 17 shooting and setting new personal bests with eight rebounds, seven assists and five steals.

And ever the finisher, 16 of his 26 points came in the second half.

AJ DYBANTSA vs UC Riverside 

26 PTS | 8 REB | 7 AST | 0 PF pic.twitter.com/pysbEZ4v7y

‚Äî BYU Men's Basketball (@BYUMBB) December 14, 2025

‚ÄúIt was ridiculous what he just did out there,‚Äù Young said of Dybantsa. ‚ÄúI mean, he had 26 points, eight rebounds, seven assists, five steals, one block, and probably could have had 50 (points), truly. He‚Äôs a special player. That was incredible what he was doing out there. I‚Äôm just incredibly impressed with what he did tonight and what he‚Äôs done all season. The kid‚Äôs good, man, and then everyone feeds off him.

‚Äú... We‚Äôre gonna win a lot of games because of how good he is, but you know, it‚Äôs more about he‚Äôs good because he‚Äôs talented, but he‚Äôs a team guy. They‚Äôre hard to find, man. They‚Äôre really hard to find.‚Äù

In addition to Dybantsa, Richie Saunders posted 10 points in the game‚Äôs first four minutes to end up with a total of 19 points and five rebounds.

Rob Wright III scored nine points with six assists, and remaining starters Keba Keita and Kennard Davis Jr. teamed up for 10 points and 13 rebounds.

here's your regularly scheduled Keba rim rocker

üì∫ESPN+ pic.twitter.com/NvGQo4A3XQ

‚Äî BYU Men's Basketball (@BYUMBB) December 14, 2025

Leading BYU‚Äôs encouraging bench charge was backup point guard Aleksej Kostiƒá, who drained five 3-pointers ‚Äî including a heat check of three in a row in the first half ‚Äî for 15 points, four assists and a plus/minus of +36 in 22 minutes to draw chants of his name from the ROC student section by game‚Äôs end.

‚ÄúHis shot making is a beautiful thing. I mean, that‚Äôs why we brought him here,‚Äù Young said of Kostiƒá. ‚ÄúWe felt like it was a matter of time before he was able to have a game like he had tonight.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs kind of a hybrid between like Trevin (Knell) from last year and Dawson (Baker) because he can play with the ball a little bit more off the dribble, and if he can do that, man, that‚Äôs going to be obviously a huge weapon for us. Especially when we sub Rob out, he can do that next to AJ. I like that pairing.‚Äù

Kostiƒá was joined in his bench excellence by redshirt freshman Khadim Mboup, who notched his first career double-double with 12 points and 10 rebounds.

But Kostiƒá‚Äôs night carries a great deal of significance ‚Äî having the Austrian newcomer serve as BYU‚Äôs ball-handling and sharpshooting option off the bench going forward would be massive in filling the crucial role left by previous sixth man Baker following his season-ending knee injury.

‚ÄúI always try to stay ready, and when I come in the game, try to shoot. I wouldn‚Äôt say it was something different that I did today. I just shoot the ball, and today I made a lot,‚Äù Kostiƒá said.

‚Äú... It‚Äôs of course, very sad that we lose a player like Dawson. They told me that I will have a bigger role, and I‚Äôll try to stay ready and step in his footsteps.‚Äù

BYU, now 9-1 on the season and 3-0 at home, will be back at the Marriott Center Tuesday night to face former WCC foe Pacific in the Cougars‚Äô third-to-last contest before the start of Big 12 play in January.

title: FNF Southern Quality Ford Dealers Scholar-Athlete of the Week: Mandeville‚Äôs Nick Ingram
description: Mandeville's Nick Ingram is our Friday Night Football Scholar Athlete of the Week.
fullText:
MANDEVILLE, La. (WGNO) ‚Äî Once Mandeville defensive end Nick Ingram got to high school, he hit the books just like he hits the opposition. It paid off, as he has a 4.62 GPA and a score of 34 on the ACT.

‚ÄúIn junior high, I was not very focused on school. But in high school, I really started focusing on my academics,‚Äù Ingram said. ‚ÄúLooking at where I am today, I am proud of what I have done. My GPA, my test scores, all that stuff.‚Äù

Ingram is an AP scholar with multiple outstanding student awards. His academic success stems from making the classroom his top priority.

‚ÄúAcademics are very important to me. As important as football, if not more important,‚Äù Ingram said. ‚ÄúIf you have a 2.0 GPA, you‚Äôre not going to get into a great school since you don‚Äôt have the academics for it.‚Äù

Ingram‚Äôs intelligence has also translated to the trenches.

‚ÄúNick helps us get lined up in formation. Makes our checks on defense in the box with the front six, he‚Äôs been very helpful there,‚Äù Mandeville head coach Craig Jones said.

Nick is uncertain of where he‚Äôll attend college, but his work as president of the Mandeville youth and government program has helped pave the way for a bright future.

‚ÄúI think I‚Äôll double major in political science and public policy. It‚Äôll allow me to go into a field with law, so I will probably go to law school afterwards,‚Äù Ingram said.

Mandeville‚Äôs Nick Ingram is our Friday Night Football Scholar Athlete of the Week, brought to you by your Southern Quality Ford Dealers.

title: Haway The Podcast | MATCHDAY PREVIEW | Derby Day | Remembering Gary Rowell
description: Join Martin, Andrew, Jonny and Ant to look ahead to the Derby ‚Äì and pay tribute to Gary Rowell.
fullText:
Good morning and welcome to Haway The Podcast on Derby Day.

Martin, Andrew, Ant and Jonny got together on Saturday morning to preview the game against Newcastle game today, however the sad news of Gary Rowell‚Äôs passing broke last night, which puts a whole different dimension on the game today.

Martin and Andrew got together again to record a short tribute to Gary, before we get into the game itself. The lads discuss.

‚Ä¢ How big a game is this in Premier League terms?

‚Ä¢ What formation will we go with?

‚Ä¢ Who‚Äôll play on the wings? This seems like the biggest selection problem for Regis today.

‚Ä¢ And the lads give us their score predictions.

This episode of Haway The Podcast is sponsored by¬†LiveScoreBet, a principal partner of Sunderland AFC.

title: Starting XI: How Will Sunderland Line Up For The Derby?
description: Is this the team to take on the mags?
fullText:
Well, here it is folks ‚Äì the game we‚Äôve all been ‚Äòlooking forward to‚Äô. Putting aside all of the noise surrounding the fixture, it‚Äôs going to be intriguing from a team selection persepective as to how Regis Le Bris approaches this game. Will we attack from the off or will we try to to soak up their energy before countering? Will we go five at the back or will we be confident in a four? How will our young players adapt to the atmosphere? Loads of questions to be answered during the course of the game ‚Äì¬†but here‚Äôs how I think we‚Äôll go into the match today.

Roefs has been exceptional this season, and his ability to claim the ball in his box will be vital today.

I think we‚Äôll go with a back four today, as we won‚Äôt want to give Newcastle a numerical advantage in midfield ‚Äì that said, I think it‚Äôll be a fluid formation that will enable us to switch with ease. Reinildo‚Äôs back after missing City, which is great news, and I think we‚Äôll see Nordi at right back, with Ballard and Alderete in the centre of the defence.

Xhaka and Sadiki thankfully came through the City game, and they‚Äôll line up in the centre of midfield ‚Äì with Le Fee in there too. I think Le Fee‚Äôs all round game will be important today and we‚Äôll see him in the thick of the action. The wings are interesting ‚Äì¬†I have a feeling we‚Äôll see a surprise here, with Trai Hume replicating the role he did later on against Bournemouth and at Liverpool, which gives us strength in front of Mukiele and a bit more protection for Le Fee, too. On the other wing, I‚Äôm taking a flyer here and going with Simon Adingra ‚Äì¬†he‚Äôs been left out of the AFCON squad and will have a point to prove. Talbi‚Äôs looked a bit indifferent out there in recent games and it‚Äôs probably too big an occasion for Mundle to start, so I‚Äôm thinking Adingra might get the nod today.

This is a tough one to call as there are compelling arguments for both Brobbey and Isidor to start ‚Äì however I think Brobbey‚Äôs strength and experience will get the nod to start, with the plan of Isidor coming on for the last 30 against tiring legs. We‚Äôll see‚Ä¶

title: On This Day (14th Dec 2024): Sunderland‚Äôs March Back Continues
description: Who would have thought at 2-0 down to Swansea that a year on it would be time for a Wear-Tyne derby?
fullText:
Christmas comes earlier every year supposedly, but for Sunderland fans it currently feels as if the club is light years on from where it was 12 months ago, when a remarkable come from behind win against Swansea City had us all in raptures.

We are just 365 days on from that trip to Wales but compare the squad from that match with the team now expected to line up against Newcastle United this afternoon and you will get a real sense for the rate of progress since then. At best there will be three, but most likely fewer, players still involved in the starting XI that were around last season, but whilst some of their old teammates have since dropped out of the picture their roles were essential at the time.

The promotion winners of 2024-25 helped usher in a new sense of hope at SAFC that has supporters looking very much ahead. It wasn‚Äôt all that long ago that people were unsure of what to make of head coach R√©gis Le Bris however, with the summer appointment experiencing a loss of momentum in the build-up to Last Christmas.

Prior to that, the Lads had been flying under their new French connector. Four Championship wins out of four, with just one goal conceded during the run, had Sunderland leading the fledgling table and it wasn‚Äôt until a run of five successive draws that they fell out of the automatic spots. An unfortunate defeat to fellow promotion hopefuls Sheffield United then cast further doubt on the push, with some wondering if Le Bris had just been enjoying a touch of ‚Äòbeginners luck‚Äô ‚Äì only for their fears to be eased when the team showed real determination to see off Stoke City in filthy weather conditions and then grab an equaliser against Bristol City a couple of days after.

Patrick Robert‚Äôs last gasp leveller against the Robins certainly set things up nicely ahead of a game with the Swans, but for all it was celebrated that fight-back soon paled into insignificance in terms of drama when put up against the resurgence seen in Glamorgan ‚Äì Le Bris‚Äô men proving beyond all doubt that they had the mental strength needed to achieve their aims.

The Jacks had initially taken an early lead through Zan Vipotnik, who capitalised on some defensive hesitancy to score from close range. Having then tested Anthony Patterson, Liam Cullen added a second less than 20 minutes in with a free kick to leave shell shocked Sunderland looking very uncertain, but it wasn‚Äôt long before they pulled themselves round ‚Äì and getting back into things before half-time handed them a vital lifeline.

Dan Ballard did well to angle a header into the net as he connected with a set piece that had been whipped into the box by Trai Hume, and once the break was over the Lads started moving building up a head of steam. Now looking more composed and able to push men forward, a string of chances was created before Dan Neil levelled things up with a screamer. Collecting the ball from Jobe, the captain drove through the middle of the park before firing in an unstoppable 20-yard effort, and whilst he was keen to get back on with the action as soon as possible the celebrations that followed the next goal were much more prolonged.

Swansea were the ones that were rocking now, but unlike their opponents they were unable to gather themselves and just two minutes on from Neil‚Äôs excellent solo strike they found themselves behind, albeit this Sunderland goal was via an excellent team move. Hume, Patrick Roberts and Chris Rigg worked down the right-hand side before the ball was put on a plate for Jobe to smash past Lawrence Vigouroux, and with the turn around complete wild scenes behind the goal followed.

With the players as ecstatic as the supporters the ‚Äòlimbs‚Äô shown suggested that everybody in red and white knew that this was big. The three points were a massive confidence boost and helped keep the squad in the promotion frame, making this game a pivotal step towards what came afterwards. Since plunging into League One many players have come and gone, and whilst several of them failed to make an impact the ones that did aid the revival will always be valued. Jon McLaughlan for example, an unused substitute for Swansea on this day, did what he could, and the ones that built on that to deliver two promotions and get the club back to where it now is did so, like they did in Wales, by keeping going Til The End‚Ä¶

Swansea City 2 (Vipotnik 5‚Äô, Cullen 17‚Äô)

Sunderland 3 (Ballard 28‚Äô, Neil 73‚Äô, Jobe 75‚Äô)

Sunderland: Patterson; Hume, Mepham, Ballard, Cirkin (O‚ÄôNien 70‚Äô); Rigg, Neil, Jobe; Roberts, Isidor, Mayenda Unused: Moore, Hjelde, Alese, Jones, Aleksiƒá, Aouchiche, Rusyn, Connolly.

Swansea.com Stadium, attendance 15,791

title: Gary Rowell: A Dear Club Legend
description: Mark Wood pays tribute to club legend Gary Rowell, whose sad passing was announced last night.
fullText:
At Roker Report, we have put together a number of tributes to ex-players and club legends down the years, but this feels like one of the most difficult.

Gary Rowell was a true club legend, and his hat-trick at St. James Park will forever be cemented in club folklore.

He had earned a legendary status among my own generation of Sunderland fans who saw him play, which he carried on long after he hung up his boots.¬† His death at a way too early 68 years old, announced in the late hours of Saturday evening and on the eve of the first Wear-Tyne derby for almost 10 years, is sad news for all Sunderland fans.

While the man will be mourned among the fanbase, he left us with some of the most amazing memories in a red and white shirt.

Gary Rowell was Sunderland through and through. Born in Seaham, he came through the ranks at the club, first making a few appearances for Bob Stokoe‚Äôs promotion-winning side of 1976 before making his breakthrough as a first-team regular the following season.

As Sunderland toiled desperately at the foot of the First Division, the new manager Jimmy Adamson called on the youth of Gary, Shaun Elliott and Kevin Arnott to form a new midfield which nearly and so spectacularly saved the club from relegation.

Although playing in midfield at this point in his career, Gary, as well as having an eye for a pass, also weighed in with some crucial goals,notably in a 4-0 win against Middlesbrough, a 6-1 win against West Brom, and a 6-0 win against West Ham.¬† All in consecutive home games.

The following season, he began to operate in a more advanced role and began to make a name for himself as a goal scorer ‚Äì 19 in all competitions -, but his career really began to take off in the 1978-79 season.¬† Twenty-four goals in thirty-nine appearances ‚Äì¬†and one game Sunderland fans will remember forever.¬† 24 February 1979 at St. James Park. Sunderland win 4-1 and Gary Rowell scored a hattrick.

A bad injury a few weeks later somewhat interrupted his progress, and some might say took away some of his pace, but when he did come back into the first team, Sunderland were back in the top flight, and Gary had not lost any of his prowess in front of goal.¬† From the summer of 1980 to the summer of 1984, he was the club‚Äôs leading goal scorer in each season, and from 1977-78 to 1984, he was the club‚Äôs leading scorer in each season bar one.¬† There was another hat-trick against Arsenal along the‚Äô way, and it‚Äôs fair to say that those goals did so much to keep Sunderland in the First Division.

He was also a penalty taker of some repute and only ever missed one in 26 attempts.¬† Watching him take a penalty you could see why ‚Äì he was very cool, and hit them low, hard and into the corner, a technique which even many of the very best players would love to master.

All in all, Gary Rowell hit 103 goals in 297 games for Sunderland and it was a complete shock to all fans when he was released by the club at just 26 years of age.

He still had a couple of outstanding memories to share with Sunderland fans after he left.

The first was in the League Cup Final of 1985 at Wembley when he was a Norwich player ‚Äì although injured ‚Äì he walked around the pitch at the final whistle with the celebrating Norwich squad, but paused in front of the Sunderland fans to chat and sign autographs with them and donned a Sunderland scarf.¬† He looked for all the world like he wanted to be standing on the terraces with us.

About a year and a half ago, I wrote a ‚ÄòSunderland Great‚Äô article which featured him, and while researching it, I saw a thread mentioning that he had not been well, which I and everyone who got wind of it hoped was not true. Unfortunately, it transpired it was.

It is awfully sad news, but despite the loss we feel as fans the thoughts of everyone should be with his family.

The second memory is also from the ‚ÄòSunderland Great‚Äô article and one that sums up the man.

May 5, 1996, and Peter Reid‚Äôs Sunderland are at Tranmere, riding the crest of a wave, confirmed as champions with the fans in full voice.

Midway through the second half and from my seat among the home support I see the whole of the Sunderland support in the stand to my right turn around singing to one guy half way up. ‚ÄôWe all live in a Gary Rowell World‚Äô.

And it is him, sitting and giving a big grin and a cheery wave back.¬†He absolutely loved it, and while not being at St. James that day but despite witnessing who knows how many of his goals, it is the memory of him I‚Äôll take all day long. Sat in the middle of the Sunderland fans, loving being the centre of attention with a great big smile on his face.

The Sunderland fans would sing ‚Äò Gary Rowell is Magic‚Äô.¬†He was.¬†Gary Rowell was completely bloody magic.¬† He‚Äôll be sorely missed, but never forgotten.

title: Match Preview: Sunderland v Newcastle United ‚Äî It‚Äôs The One We‚Äôve Been Waiting For!
description: We‚Äôve waited almost ten years, and today is the day!
fullText:
TV/Stream: Full live match coverage is available via Sky Sports.

Radio: Full live match commentary available via BBC Radio Newcastle (not online)

Don‚Äôt forget to follow the blow-by-blow account of the game on the Roker Report Twitter feed (@RokerReport) and check out the player ratings after the full-time whistle at www.RokerReport.sbnation.com!

It‚Äôs a few months short of a decade since we last took this lot on in the Premier League, but the fifteen games we‚Äôve had so far this season have all seemingly built up to this.

The gap between the two sides over the last seven years or so has arguably never been bigger, and it‚Äôs a good reminder that it was only around three-and-a-half years ago that we beat Wycombe to climb out of League One, and just shy of two years since we were shown how far we still had to come.

We now take on Newcastle, a point ahead of them in the Premier League table, as we approach the midway point in the season, and with an unbeaten record at home so far. We‚Äôve played them in the play-offs in the past, and when both sides have been struggling at the wrong end of the table, but today feels like a victory would feel hugely symbolic.

Newcastle fans were likely feeling comfortable that we wouldn‚Äôt be around to compete for a long time to come. Still, the accelerated progress has led us from League One play-offs to competing as equals in under four years, and we‚Äôre making the most of it. Whatever happens, we know we‚Äôre back, but it would be the cherry on top of a stupidly big sundae if we collect three points today.

We‚Äôve mentioned our unbeaten record at home, and Eddie Howe‚Äôs side had a timely reminder of what it feels like to win on the road a fortnight ago ‚Äì as they beat a very poor Everton for their first win away from home this season. Three draws and three defeats make up the other six, and it remains their weakness on paper this season.

The expectations were high after collecting more than half the total of our summer outlay from Liverpool for Isak, but three wins in the first eleven fell short of what they hoped. Three wins and a draw in the last four have improved the picture, but they didn‚Äôt have it all their own way at home to Burnley last weekend, and the trip to Germany with Bayer Leverkusen scoring a late equaliser.

However, that occurrence in midweek isn‚Äôt anything new, with Newcastle conceding nine goals in the final ten minutes of games in all competitions this season. The goal in Germany had the players, manager, and pundits all questioning their mentality.

With the effort of midweek and the visit of Chelsea at the weekend, and a trip to Old Trafford coming quickly after that, they‚Äôll know that their biggest test out of those could be today.

The bookies have the Lads at 9/4 to win the game, while that lot are priced at 6/5, and the draw is 9/4.

[Ballard (OG) 35‚Äô, Isak 46‚Äô, 90‚Äô (pen)]

Sunderland: Patterson, Hume, O‚ÄôNien, Ballard, Alese, Ekwah, Neil, Pritchard, Bellingham, Clarke, Rusyn (Ba) Substitutes not used: Bishop, Pembele, Seelt, Triantis, Rigg, Aouchiche, Hemir, Burstow

Newcastle United: Dubravka, Trippier, Burn (Dummett), Guimaraes, Schar (Lascelles), Botman, Almiron (Livramento), Longstaff, Isak, Joelinton (Miley), Gordon (Ritchie) Substitutes not used: Karius, Krafth, Hall

Well, it‚Äôs usually a choice between 2-1 or 3-0‚Ä¶ so I‚Äôm going 2-1.

title: Nevada Survives Another Nail Biter in 78-75 Win over Duquesne
description: Another down to the wire game, and now it‚Äôs time for conference play.
fullText:
Nevada hosted Duquesne on Saturday night, a game that wasn‚Äôt 100 percent guaranteed to happen. A power outage hit the north side of campus, which included Lawlor Events Center. The outage forced the Nevada women‚Äôs game to go into a no-contest and there was uncertainty if it would be back on in time for the men‚Äôs tip-off.

Luckily, power was restored, and a win was granted to Nevada, beating Duquesne 78-75 in another nail-biter that came down to the wire. This game was a constant momentum shift, with both sides trading off dominant runs and long scoring droughts.

Nevada was playing behind to start, but Chuck Bailey was keeping Nevada in it early on. Six of Nevada‚Äôs eight early points came from Bailey inside.

The offense took advantage of the Duke‚Äôs scoring drought, going on a 15-0 run that included a three-pointer by Peyton White, giving Nevada its first lead of the game. White hit a mid-range jumper followed by three from Amire Robinson, giving Nevada a quick seven point lead in a matter of minutes.

Nevada‚Äôs offense just kept on pounding. A 25-6 run over a span of 10 minutes helped give the Wolf Pack a lead as high as 14 points toward the end of the first half. Nearly half of Nevada‚Äôs points in that first half came from inside the paint as it took a 42-35 lead into halftime. Nevada also shot over 50 percent from the field in the first half.

A hot start to the second half for Duquesne was a cold one for Nevada. The Pack collected eight points to open up before hitting a scoring drought, allowing Duquesne to close within a few points. The drought lasted a little over three minutes before freshman Myles Walker hit a three to extend the game to 53-49.

It was off and on for Nevada‚Äôs offense from there, which allowed the Dukes to tie and then take the lead on a Nevada scoring drought that lasted over three minutes. A free throw by Elijah Price and a layup by Tayshawn Comer allowed Nevada to retake a slim 72-71 lead with 1:13 to go.

It came down to free throws, which Nevada made 24-32 to seal a close 78-75 win. Nevada went 7-8 from the free-throw line in the final minute of the half to seal its eighth win.

‚ÄúWhat can you say about your freshmen, Myles [Walker] and Peyton [White], who continue to make veteran plays,‚Äù Alford said. ‚ÄúThat was a highly contested game, down to the wire, and you got two freshmen going to the line the last two trips and go 4-4 at the line, that‚Äôs big time.‚Äù

Duquesne opened up the game with two quick threes on some missed defensive switches for Nevada. There were two quick turnovers for the Pack in the first seven minutes of the half that turned into six points for the Dukes.

After going up by eight for a 16-8 lead, Duquesne went on a scoring drought of over five minutes. The Dukes also gave up three turnovers in that span. They broke out of the dry spell just under the 10-minute mark with another shot beyond the arc.

Duquesne closed the gap a bit but didn‚Äôt shoot the best in the first half, going 36 percent from the field and 39 percent from beyond the arc. Guards Tarence Guinyard and Jimmie Williams both collected double digits in that first half, but the rest of the Duke‚Äôs offense was slow. Guinyard ended the night as the Dukes‚Äô lead scorer with 21 points on 5-11 shooting.

The Dukes opened the second half with much more pace, leading to a 7-0 run before Nevada had to take a timeout.

It was much more tight-knit within the final 10 minutes, as both sides traded momentum. With 2:04 to go, Duquesne made a three to tie the game at 69 and used a turnover to take the lead in the middle of a 9-0 run. All in all, Nevada‚Äôs defense may have played hot potato, but it closed it out when it needed to. Duquesne finished shooting 39 percent from the field and 33 from three.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think our start and finish in the first half was very good defensively,‚Äù head coach Steve Alford said. ‚ÄúIn the middle, it was really good, and then to start the second half was bad, but we closed out some good stops.‚Äù

Nevada will begin conference play next weekend, and it‚Äôll do it from the comfort of its own home. The Wolf Pack will host rival Boise State on Saturday, Dec. 20, at Lawlor. Tip-off is scheduled for 7 p.m. PST.

The Broncos are coming off a dominant win over Duquesne a week ago and will be playing St Mary‚Äôs tomorrow night.

‚ÄúBeat ‚Äòem [Boise State],‚Äù Amire Robinson said about what the mindset is going into the first conference game of the year. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt come out good against Duquesne, and they beat Duquesne pretty good, so we got to shove back and really kill them this time.‚Äù

title: Today Is The Day To Make More Memories!
description: ‚ÄúThis is what a derby is ‚Äî memories passed from one generation to the next‚Äù, writes Michael Dunne.
fullText:
My first ever Sunderland game was on 24 February 2002 ‚Äî a Wear-Tyne Derby.

This was the first game my father brought me to and I recall the build up like it happened yesterday. The face paint, putting on my Sunderland jersey with ‚ÄúPhillips‚Äù on the back (because the club shop had run out of the numbers 1 and 0!) and the increasing sense of trepidation and anticipation as the kick off time approached.

We lost that game 0-1 due to the magnificent performance of Shay Given in the Newcastle goal, and it crushed me as an Irish goalkeeper destroyed a little eight year old Irish boy‚Äôs dreams on his first trip to Sunderland.

The heartbreak didn‚Äôt last too long, as like the resilient Sunderland fan I‚Äôve become, you learn to grudgingly accept defeat and chase that next high; the next opportunity to roar, to celebrate a goal and to hug the ones close to you when these moments occur.

As some may already know, I‚Äôm not from the area nor the country, but my passion for this club goes back to the beginning of my supporting days back in 2002.

It was the way the people made me feel on my first trip with the Irish Sunderland Supporters Club, as it was then. How the Belfast branch dressed me up for the occasion with their face paint and scarves, and how I would readily begin a conversation with anyone in the city who would talk Sunderland AFC with me.

The Sunderland AFC I knew back then was lost along the way ‚Äî through chaos, decline and ridicule ‚Äî but it‚Äôs fought its way back to become something we can believe in again.

Today, my father and I will fly from Dublin to see our team take on their greatest enemy almost twenty five years on from that trip, and we‚Äôll be there with immense pride in where Kyril Louis-Dreyfus, Kristjaan Speakman and R√©gis Le Bris have brought the club in such a short space of time.

For years, this club has been the butt of a joke, the laughing stock of the football community and Netflix‚Äôs black comedy success story, but that Sunderland is well and truly gone.

In many ways, this edition of the derby is an opportunity for the players but especially the fans to announce that we aren‚Äôt the jokers anymore. It‚Äôs another opportunity for this club to show that it belongs here and to seize the moment and the occasion.

We‚Äôre a proud fanbase but we‚Äôre also a fanbase that‚Äôll back our players to the hilt once we see the effort on the pitch. Today, we must match the effort on the pitch with noise that‚Äôll rattle in the stands and that a young kid will remember for a lifetime ‚Äî just like I did twenty five years ago.

Despite my confident prediction that we‚Äôll win, today is another chapter on the new story of Sunderland AFC. It could be the day that a new generation of fans will be hooked by this incredible football club, and it‚Äôs a day to make new memories.

Long after the result is forgotten, it won‚Äôt be the scoreline that remains.

Instead, it‚Äôll be the walk to the ground, the nervous laughter, the roar that shakes your chest, and the arms you find yourself wrapped in when the ball hits the Newcastle net. This is what a derby is ‚Äî memories passed from one generation to the next. And today, once again, we go to make another one.

title: Reader‚Äôs Corner ‚Äì Remembering Gary Rowell
description: Roker Report reader Keith Davison has shared his memories of Gary Rowell with us.
fullText:
Gary Rowell‚Äôs greatest moment was probably the hat trick he scored against Newcastle in a 4-1 win for the Lads away at Sid James Park.

In 1979 I was just a na√Øve teenager scared of my own shadow and definitely scared of football ‚Äòhooligans‚Äô. But football was my obsession, and when my older and much more street-wise brother (who had a bit of hooligan experience himself) suggested that the best way to watch the derby at Sid James was to go incognito amongst the bar codes, I jumped at the idea.

We‚Äôd then be able to travel to and from the ground amongst them and be safer than if we went in the away end and then had to get away home as being obviously from Sunderland.

Younger readers will be shocked to hear that in those days you could just turn up to a ground on the day of the match and pay at the gate. No all-ticket matches, no purchase history required, no BCPs. This was a reasonable enough idea and did work in terms of getting us to the game safely.

What we hadn‚Äôt contemplated and planned for was the Lads winning 4-1 and Lord Rowell scoring a hat trick.

You can imagine what the atmosphere was like among the mags at seeing their team dismantled by Rowell that day with a clinical display of finishing. You will also be able to imagine what it was like to be a Sunderland supporter being amongst this angry mob and not being able to celebrate.

I was later to discover that at 4-1 up Rowell had a discussion with Kevin Arnott about whether to go for a 5th goal or to just to take the piss. Apparently they decided to take the piss and annoy the locals more. Thanks lads.

Anyway, we did make it out of the ground safely and went back to the multi-storey car park where we had parked up. We got into the car park lift alongside an old couple returning from a shopping trip, and finally, much to their shock, we were able to celebrate the Lads‚Äô success properly after 90 minutes of bottling it up. They must have thought we were crackers.

When I think of Rowell I find it difficult to describe him and his attributes. He wasn‚Äôt fast and skilful like Marco, he couldn‚Äôt dribble around teams like McGeady or even Nedum Onuoha. He wasn‚Äôt a tackler like Cattermole or Bally.

What he did do was score goals. He always seemed to be in the right place or just be able to create the right amount of space to get a shot away. He never seemed to blast the ball into the net ‚Äì it was always more of a pass right into the corner of the net and out of the keeper‚Äôs reach. I don‚Äôt recall him scoring many spectacular goals ‚Äì I just remember him scoring lots of goals.

I remember when he first came into the team I thought he was just going to be a fairly steady midfield player. He didn‚Äôt particularly stand out, but gradually, as Stokoe began to shake up the cup-winning team from 1973, and then Stokoe himself left, Rowell went from being a bit-part player to our leading man and top goal scorer. When he was joined in the first team by Arnott and Elliott the sudden burst of youthful enthusiasm totally revived the team.
I never met the man, but nothing I have heard about him would lead me to think anything other of him than ‚Äì Gary Rowell, a true Sunderland legend, one of our own, and a boyhood hero of my generation.

title: Score Predictions: Can Sunderland See Off The Mags At Home?
description: It‚Äôs the big one. The game we‚Äôve all been waiting for: Newcastle at home. Time to step up, Lads!
fullText:
Score prediction: Sunderland 2 Newcastle 1

Sunderland‚Äôs first goalscorer: Granit Xhaka

A big, big day on Wearside. This is a huge game in our resurgence ‚Äî and a win here could be the cherry on top of what‚Äôs been an exceptional 2025.

It‚Äôll be a tough game, but I‚Äôm hoping beyond hope that we can get the win today, which will be worth more than three points.

First scorer? Xhaka to lead by example in a tense, tight and nervy win.

Score prediction: Sunderland 2 Newcastle 0

Sunderland‚Äôs first goalscorer: Wilson Isidor

The Lads have had a full week off to rest, recover and train ready for today. They‚Äôll be ready for battle and baying for blood after the disappointment of a 3-0 loss away to Manchester City last weekend.

That passion for victory should especially be the case against this collection of over-entitled pond life, who seem to think since winning the League Cup, they‚Äôre even more of ‚Äúthe dog‚Äôs nob‚Äù than before, and it‚Äôs our turn to wake up this bunch of self indulgent, tree-felling, oppressive-regime-loving saddos.

We‚Äôre back, we‚Äôre on the up, and you‚Äôre next. Can you deal with the 2025/2026 version of Sunderland AFC? I don‚Äôt think so.

Monologues aside, Newcastle have had a wee resurgence of late, closing the points gap behind us well, but they‚Äôll be tired from their midweek Champions League game and I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôll have absolutely no idea about the wall of red and white which is about to hit them at 100mph.

Isidor is going to get our first for me, using his pace against a less-than-mobile backline ‚Äî including Dan ‚ÄúThe Tanker‚Äù Burn.

Dan Ballard will get a second early in the second half to get his own back for that deflected own goal in the cup game, and we‚Äôll cruise the rest of the game without incident, wondering what all the fuss was about.

I‚Äôve manifested it, lads. Go and do it. It‚Äôs nothing less than you‚Äôre capable of.

Score prediction: Sunderland 3 Newcastle 1

Sunderland‚Äôs first goalscorer: Enzo Le F√©e

Are you nervous yet? Because they are.

It‚Äôs to our great credit that we go into this game one point ahead of our rivals and I‚Äôm sure that despite the usual nonsense spouted, they know they‚Äôre coming into a real game after a slow start to their Premier League season.

I expect it to be a physical, fast-paced affair. They like to mix it (see also: ‚Äúcheat‚Äù) and can break with speed, so our midfield maestro Granit Xhaka will be pivotal in keeping us organised and driving us on against a set of robust players.

Another tiring trip for Newcastle in midweek to drop points again at Bayer Leverkusen will have taken its toll, and we have to take full advantage of that. Having Noah Sadiki and his outrageous energy against a team who‚Äôve already played once this week looks even more dangerous now ‚Äî thank the red and white gods that those yellow cards were avoided.

I fancy Le F√©e to follow in the footsteps of Patrice Carteron and Djibril Ciss√©, with a tenacious display and a sumptuous goal to go with it.

The Stadium of Light has proved a fortress so far this season but on Sunday, we prepare for war.

Score prediction: Sunderland 2 Newcastle 0

Sunderland‚Äôs first goalscorer: Noah Sadiki

All the noise this week has been from them: excuses, downplaying it and pretending they‚Äôre not rattled. But they know exactly what‚Äôs waiting at 2:00pm: a Stadium of Light that‚Äôs been itching for this.

We look built for this battle; Granit Xhaka running the show, Dan Ballard and Omar Alderete as solid as granite, and Noah Sadiki ready to outrun every black and white shirt in sight. Hit them early, win the duels, keep the tempo high, and this is our game to grab.

I fancy Sadiki to spark it off: press, pinch it, slot it, bedlam.

Derbies come down to desire. And this time, it‚Äôs our lads who want it more.

Score prediction: Newcastle 2 Sunderland 1

Sunderland‚Äôs first goalscorer: Dan Ballard

Forget the years spent lost in the doldrums of League One. Forget the sneering Mags who laughed at our misfortune and forget the 0-3 in the FA Cup, because this time, we meet them as equals.

The superiority complex runs deep on the dark side of the North East and the narrative is that this is their ‚Äúthird most important game of the week‚Äù.

That‚Äôs fine. Underestimate us at your peril, because I have no doubt these lads know exactly what this means to the fans.

This is their chance to write themselves into folklore and to become heroes on Wearside.

Score prediction: Sunderland 5 Newcastle 1

Sunderland‚Äôs first goalscorer: Dan Ballard

We‚Äôre going to come out all guns blazing and score three before Newcastle actually realise they‚Äôre playing.

They‚Äôll come out in the second half the better team, score a goal, and Granit Xhaka will rally the troops to punish them further until the ninetieth minute.

Score prediction: Sunderland 2 Newcastle 1

Sunderland‚Äôs first goalscorer: Dan Ballard

Form and league position can go in the bin ‚Äî it‚Äôs ninety minutes decided by who wants it more, a bit of quality, and a bit of luck.

For occasions like this, we have the players I want in my team: Granit Xhaka, Dan Ballard, Omar Alderete, Nordi Mukiele, Reinildo, Noah Sadiki‚Ä¶and I could go on.

I have full confidence in the Lads that they understand the importance of this game and how much it means to the fans and the city. And they‚Äôll certainly feel that on the day, just when they thought they understood.

As long as they show the unwavering commitment on the pitch that we‚Äôve seen already, and strike a balance with their emotions, I believe we‚Äôll win this match.

Ballard getting the first goal would be immense and a signal of how far he‚Äôs grown since the last time.

The Mags don‚Äôt get to play this fixture down now it‚Äôs here and tell us we are over the top, whilst it‚Äôs not as big a game for them ‚Äî you‚Äôre not fooling us.

There‚Äôs too many receipts out there, and we‚Äôre here to collect.

Score prediction: Sunderland 3 Newcastle 0

Sunderland‚Äôs first goalscorer: Granit Xhaka

The boys did OK for the first third of the game at Manchester City, but when we were undone by a deflection and then a set piece, it rapidly became clear this run was simply too much with tough games in quick succession. The third City goal was quality that we simply can‚Äôt argue against. Lovely stuff ‚Äî sadly against us and not by us.

We had some great chances for Enzo Le F√©e, Granit Xhaka and Wilson Isidor and on another day, two or even all three of them would‚Äôve gone in rather than narrowly missing, hitting the woodwork or being saved.

It was a step too far to face Liverpool and City away and so close to each other, but we left with our heads held high, and now we need to focus on the big one.

Most of the lads went for either a loss or a draw, with the odd outlier, which brought in just a few points for a few of the team.

No points for first scorer as nobody went for a loss to nil, either.

Minor moves in the table only, with only four points between sixth place and top.

Four points is exactly what you get for the right score and first scorer.

Easy for anyone to rally across Christmas, then!

Just a quick reminder of how we allocate points to our match-by-match predictions:

Correct outcome (but not correct score) = One point

Correct first Sunderland goalscorer = One point (no goalscorer is a valid call)

Possible deductions for being lazy and not submitting on time = a two-point deduction.

title: Lake Mary wins 1st Florida state championship on the wildest Hail Mary ending in FHSAA history
description: No way in the world this happened.
fullText:
Lake Mary wins 1st Florida state championship on the wildest Hail Mary ending in FHSAA history originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

One of the most improbable endings to a football game in the history of this magnificent sport took place Saturday night in Florida, with Lake Mary High School trailing 27-21 to Vero Beach before the final play of the game.

But then came one of the craziest Hail Mary plays ever seen.

The deep ball was batted down, but then caught by a Lake Mary player. But then the tackle appeared to be made, before a lateral to another player resulted in getting the ball into the end zone.

The pass was thrown by Noah Grubbs.

It fell into the arms of Barrett Schulz.

He found¬†Tavarius Brundridge Jr. racing around him to get the ball.

Hard to believe this just happened. Lake Mary 28 Vero Beach 27 - INSANE FINISH in the FHSAA Class 7A state championship (@LMRamsFootball) pic.twitter.com/dxAZsye1qs

‚Äî MaxPreps (@MaxPreps) December 14, 2025

It's the first state championship ever for Lake Mary, coming in the FHSAA Class 7A final.

Sports are just absolutely crazy. How in the world does this happen?

It's just magic, mixed with elation on one side and heartbreak on the other.

Lake Mary is atop the state in a manner and moment they'll never forget.

description: (WFRV) ‚Äî It was a packed week of high school hoops around Northeast Wisconsin, with the highlight being Appleton East‚Äôs big win over Kimberly girls basketball (a rematch of when these two teams saw each other in the WIAA Division 1 State Semifinal last season). The Patriots avenging that loss, taking down Kimberly 50-43 in [‚Ä¶]

title: ‚ÄúReinventing himself at Chelsea‚Äù ‚Äì Player tipped to join Blues soon
description: A Premier League player has been tipped to join Chelsea now very soon in a move that could see one in and one out.The news comes off the back of Chelsea getting back to winning ways yesterday afternoo...
fullText:
A Premier League player has been tipped to join Chelsea now very soon in a move that could see one in and one out.

The news comes off the back of Chelsea getting back to winning ways yesterday afternoon by beating Everton 2-0 in the Premier League. It was a game that many Blues fans had been fearing due to a rough run of form lately.

There was a bizarre reaction from Enzo Maresca after the game when he complained about the lack of support that he has been receiving lately, the worst he has experienced since he‚Äôs been at the club according to the gaffer.

It was Malo Gusto who grabbed the decisive second goal in the game to finish things off in what was a fine overall display from the right back yesterday.

And now, another player is being tipped to join this squad under Maresca.

Kobbie Mainoo with a Chelsea and Man U logo. (Photo by Ben Roberts Photo/Getty Images)

Former Everton CEO Keith Wyness told Football Insider he‚Äôs heard Manchester United are lining up a one in, one out swap of two England internationals:

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs very unfair and I think that Mainoo, look, he‚Äôs a squandered talent in that sense. I just don‚Äôt think he‚Äôs, for some reason, he hasn‚Äôt caught [Ruben] Amorim‚Äôs eye. He thinks he doesn‚Äôt fit the style.

‚ÄúI think that they decided that Adam Wharton is going to be one of their targets and I think that Mainoo may find himself reinventing himself at Chelsea.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs where I see the situation going and that‚Äôs the whispers I‚Äôve been hearing. I think it would be good for Mainoo. I think he needs to get out of there and move forward.‚Äù

title: Slot Happy to Keep Clean Sheets
description: Liverpool‚Äôs head coach was upbeat following their 2-nil victory over Brighton.
fullText:
It‚Äôs been sometime since Liverpool have felt like the play and results have felt like they were reflective of defending champions. With their comprehensive 2-nil victory over Brighton & Hove Albion on Saturday, Liverpool can not only claim back-to-back victories, but also point to a current streak of 5 matches unbeaten.

For head coach Arne Slot, it‚Äôs clear that while the point is to bring victories, being able to keep the opposition out of the goal is a prime objective. So, it‚Äôs unsurprising that Slot would have mentioned keeping this clean sheet ‚Äì and the others within this solid run for the Reds ‚Äì within the remarks he gave following the match.

‚ÄúIn my opinion, we are starting to play better and better on the ball as well. And from the last five games we‚Äôve played, we kept three clean sheets and that is something to build on, especially after conceding four against PSV [Eindhoven] and three against Nottingham Forest.‚Äù

Lots of talk has surrounded the club, especially through the difficult stretch they seem to be climbing out of, with much of it focusing on the seeming difficulty of the coaching staff to find the right balance between defense and attack given the new offensive weapons acquired during the transfer windows. If this match were to serve as an indicator of progress on that project, though, the boss would have you think there‚Äôs more work to be done.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs funny, this is what people now say if you win 2-0 and then all of a sudden we were solid. But I think we conceded in one game more than we did in the last four games. But now all of a sudden it‚Äôs solid because we won the game. And when we had a draw or are conceding in the last minute against Leeds, I assume that people weren‚Äôt as positive as after this game.‚Äù

While it might seem harsh to assess what felt a solid victory as something that should be improved, the stats say the boss isn‚Äôt far off. According to Opta, the xG battle actually went ‚Äì ever so marginally ‚Äì towards Brighton, with a draw being a pretty fair assessment based on the data set.

Liverpool fans, though, would have found it rather harsh given how well the team looked moving forward with scuffed chances from Mohamed Salah among them. And speaking of the Egyptian goalscorer, it was inevitable given the past week that Slot would be asked about the relationship with Mo. The Dutchman gave a straightforward refusal to get drawn in, though, opting to toe a line that expressed clear respect and admiration but provided nothing in terms of specifics on the current state of things.

‚ÄúI think the reason why he wasn‚Äôt in Milan was his interview and the question is always ‚Äì and everybody has a different opinion about that ‚Äì should he be once, twice, three times, four times, four months, 12 years‚Ä¶ every manager makes [a] different decision in that. He wasn‚Äôt involved in the game against Milan, I spoke to him yesterday and usually I never say anything about what we talk about, I am not going to make an exception now but I think actions speak louder than what has been said. He was in the squad again and when I had to make my first substitution, I brought him in and he performed as I think every fan ‚Äì including me ‚Äì would like him to perform today.‚Äù

All told, it‚Äôs the type of professional media appearance you‚Äôd expect from a top-flight manager. Slot has come in for a lot of criticism over the past week with some it being warranted and a surprising amount seeming to be pot-shots at a coach trying to manage a grieving football club through a difficult patch on the pitch. It is not an excuse for the poor results, but it certainly helps me to maintain a certain perspective on Slot and the lads; that this season is a gift and the matches will be opportunities for the squad to band closer together.

It‚Äôs not the most rigorous approach to sport and fandom, but with a Premier League trophy in tow and the weight of losing a friend overshadowing things, I‚Äôm having a hard time mustering up too much angst ‚Äì even when things were going wrong. I‚Äôm happy for every day we get to see this group and, in particular, the opportunity to watch the remnants of Klopp‚Äôs core try to figure out if they‚Äôve got one more evolution in them.

I‚Äôve counted this team out before and they‚Äôve managed to surprise. Maybe, this season, it‚Äôll all click and we‚Äôll get a run of form to rival anything we‚Äôve seen before. But on the off-chance that doesn‚Äôt happen, I‚Äôm just glad this team is trending in the right direction. Progress. That‚Äôs all I need.

title: 76ers rookie named one of best NBA players under 25 years old
description: This is pretty high praise for a rookie.
fullText:
76ers rookie named one of best NBA players under 25 years old originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

One thing that the Philadelphia 76ers have been able to do relatively well over the past decade or so is infusing the roster with young talent.

Back in 2017, Joel Embiid and Ben Simmons were both ranked highly on ESPN‚Äôs list of the top NBA players under 25 years old. Embiid ranked No. 4 on the list that year, and Simmons placed 10th.

Last year, guard Tyrese Maxey came in at No. 6 on The Ringer‚Äôs iteration of the top players under 25 list. This year, it‚Äôs V.J. Edgecombe‚Äôs turn.¬†Philadelphia‚Äôs prized rookie was recently ranked¬†by ESPN as the 19th-best player under 25.

"While there have been some predictable rookie growing pains, Edgecombe has largely rewarded the 76ers' decision to pick him third, with his explosiveness attacking the paint and flashes of defensive playmaking that point to major long-term upside. The future of the franchise rests on Edgecombe and Tyrese Maxey, and how well Philly can develop them in tandem."

Edgecombe stepped right into a starting spot for the Sixers this season, and he‚Äôs been impressive. In 21 appearances, he‚Äôs averaging 14.7 points, 5.6 rebounds, 4.0 assists and 1.3 steals per performance.

While the raw numbers aren‚Äôt staggering, Edgecombe has shown the Sixers everything that they could have hoped to see from him at this early point in his career. He‚Äôs an elite athlete who can get to the rim almost at will and finish once there. He‚Äôs also shown an ability to space the floor, as he‚Äôs shooting 38 percent from long range and nearly 44 percent on catch-and-shoot opportunities from distance.

But, he‚Äôs been perhaps even more impressive on the defensive end where he‚Äôs shown the potential to be an elite perimeter defender. Last month, Sixers coach Nick Nurse even¬†referred to Edgecombe as one of the best defenders on the team. He truly has All-Defensive team talent and potential.

As we've seen with the likes of Ben Simmons, being named as one of the best players under 25 isn't a guarantee that a player's potential will be realized, but it's high praise nonetheless, especially for a rookie.

title: UFC Vegas 112 results: Manel Kape quickly crushes Brandon Royval with heavy right hook
description: Brandon Royval vs. Manel Kape squared off in a Flyweight bout earlier tonight (Sat., Dec. 13, 2025) at UFC Vegas 112 inside UFC Apex in Las Vegas, Nevada. Kape opened the fight with some chopping low kicks, pressing Royval backwards.
fullText:
Brandon Royval vs. Manel Kape squared off in a Flyweight bout earlier tonight (Sat., Dec. 13, 2025) at UFC Vegas 112 inside UFC Apex in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Kape opened the fight with some chopping low kicks, pressing Royval backwards. Royval ripped a nice body kic but absorbed a counter right hand in response. Royval was active with his kicks but didn‚Äôt commit his weight to all of them. Kape flurried forward with a couple nice body punches. Royval blasted another kick, but Kape backed him into the fence and unloaded with a vicious right hook.

Royval hit the floor in a heap! Royval tried to pop back up but found himself under a hail of fast power punches. Royval went out cold at least once and then woke back up as the referee moved to intervene. ‚ÄúRaw Dog‚Äù protested, but this was a clean KO from ‚ÄúStarboy.‚Äù

Is this Kape finally living up to his potential? He just blitzed the No. 2-ranked Flyweight in the world and made it look pretty easy. Now riding a three-fight finish streak, there‚Äôs chance we see Kape vs. Joshua Van sometime in the next few months. Between the recent victories of Kape, Kyoji Horiguchi, and Tatsuro Taira, Flyweight has really heated up!

Result: Manel Kape defeats Brandon Royval via first-round knockout

title: UFC Vegas 112 results: Manuel Kape annihilates Brandon Royval in minutes, makes case for title shot
description: The final UFC fight of 2025, and on ESPN, was a short one.
fullText:
The final UFC fight of 2025, and on ESPN, was a short one. In a battle of flyweight contenders, Manel Kape made short work of Brandon Royval with a first-round knockout Saturday at UFC Vegas 112, earning his eighth win in his past nine fights.

With such a one-sided win over a one-time title challenger, Kape made his case for a title shot against new UFC flyweight champion Joshua Van, though he might have to get in line.

The fight was fairly even for the first couple of minutes, but it ended almost immediately after Kape landed a right hook that left Royval falling to the mat. A few more strikes and referee Herb Dean had seen enough at the 3:18 mark of the opening round, even though Royval wasn't happy with the stoppage.

The last UFC fight of 2025 was ended in style by @ManelKape üò≤ #UFCVegas112pic.twitter.com/uwtIhwQ8EZ

‚Äî Uncrowned (@uncrownedcombat) December 14, 2025

Kape had a rude welcome to the UFC in 2021, suffering back-to-back losses to Alexandre Pantoja (a tough first assignment in retrospect) and Matheus Nicolau. Since then, he has been on a tear, earning three straight wins by finish since his last loss to Muhammad Mokaev. He was supposed to face Royval in June, but had to withdraw due to a broken foot.

Van took that spot and used it as a launching pad to his successful title shot against Pantoja, won via freak injury at UFC 323.

Kape took the opportunity Saturday to call out the Houston-based champ. It was one of the more colorful callouts you will ever hear:

"Joshua Van, you have my belt. If I hadn't broke my feet in July, I would be the champion right now. Now baby, listen very well. I'm here, your daddy. Your daddy is going to take your diapers, alive, on the new deal, Paramount deal. I'm going to take your diapers, alive.

"Be ready, because you are in Houston, right? Let's fight in Houston in February, or whatever you want. Just sign the contract. Houston is my city."

Kape's win doesn't make the UFC's path forward at flyweight any simpler. Tatsuro Taira was quickly presented as a natural option for Van following his own win over Brandon Moreno at UFC 323, and Pantoja had the kind of run atop the division that warrants an immediate rematch as soon as he's healthy. But Kape sure looks like a guy who can challenge for the belt soon.

Check out full UFC Vegas 112 results and highlights below.
